text: Do you remember how to say to speak?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It begins with a silent H Ablar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what is I speak or I'm speaking?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what was to sleep or to be dormant, let's say?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And how do you say I sleep?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said also that you can get the additional meaning of I fall asleep by saying I sleep myself.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I eat or I'm eating is?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So here the O doesn't split, good.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't say in Spanish to have breakfast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We have a verb to breakfast, let's say.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the verb to breakfast is desayunar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Breakfast and desayunar are direct translations of each other, in fact.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I don't know if you noticed that in English breakfast is break fast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When we have breakfast we break the fast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And in Spanish, des is like an, ayunar is to fast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So desayunar is like to unfast, to break fast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I am having breakfast or I have breakfast.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And desayuno is also the noun.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was to wait or to hope?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Desperate is related because again we have this des like in desayunar which is like unhoped or unhopeful is to be desperate.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So to wait or to hope?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What is I wait or I'm waiting or I hope or I'm hoping?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we've been giving the verbs two translations in the present tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is because this ing tense in English we really overuse it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, we use this ing in English to refer to the future.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Whereas in Spanish we just use the present tense with that future context.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which is why we need to give both translations for hace for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: He makes or does or he's making or doing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we translate hablo as I speak and I'm speaking.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But this doesn't mean that I'm speaking doesn't exist.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We use it in Spanish only when we want to show what we are doing right now in this moment.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Do you think you would choose ser for characteristics?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or do you think you would choose estar for states?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We would use estar because of course what we are doing is a state.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we'd always use estar with these structures.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the first part of this sentence is estoy.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now to get speaking ing from to speak we take off ar and we add ando.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So maybe somebody interrupts you and you won't say hablo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I am waiting?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you could say espero aquí.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe it would sound a little more like I'll wait here rather than I'm waiting here.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In many situations both are fine and there will be just a slight change in meaning.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What you can't do is say I'm meeting with her tomorrow.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The ing you need to use it just for what you're doing right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And how would you say I speak or I'm speaking?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you forgot it you can go from preparation.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And I prepare or I'm preparing?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I'm preparing it tomorrow?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you want to show, if you want to emphasize that we're doing something right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Firstly, if we divide that up into two bits.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I am preparing?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that's if you want to say I'm preparing it right now you can use this structure.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I am preparing it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Lo estoy preparando o estoy preparándolo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Even though it's a changed verb here we can have the lo after ando.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Estoy preparándolo o lo estoy preparando.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that to have breakfast was desayunar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say we are having breakfast and you mean right now?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for ar verbs we take off the ar and we put ando and we get this tense to show what we're doing right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And we're not going to use it as we do in English.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I'm preparing it later?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This is not how we use it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in Spanish we only use it to describe what we're doing right now.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is why we're giving preparo for example the translation of both I prepare and I'm preparing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that when we want to say things like I'm preparing it later we don't go to estoy preparando.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you wanted to give the meaning of I'm preparing it right now how would you say it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Estoy preparando lo o lo estoy preparando.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And there you get the meaning of right now in this moment.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for ar verbs we're taking off the ar and we're putting ando to get this ing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For ar ir verbs we take off the ar or the ir and we put on yendo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I-E-N-D-O to get this ing form.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you get eating from to eat?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would eating be from comer?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I'm eating and you mean right now?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And how would you say he is eating or she is eating or you fuman?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So maybe somebody calls you and they say can I speak to Pablo and you say está comiendo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can think of vending machine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say they sell it?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say they're selling it tomorrow or they will sell it tomorrow?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now if you want to say they're selling it right now and you want to get that meaning right now, how would it be?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Están vendiéndolo or lo están vendiendo.
speaker: Speaker 1
